Now, what first shone a big spotlight on HARD RESET as choirs of angels sung from on high
was the fact that it was developed by some of the guys who worked on PAINKILLER, that
now classic traditionalist FPS that is still more fun than any mortal sinner has any right
to have.
Presumably not the same ex-PAINKILLER guys who were brought onto Bulletstorm and found

themselves polishing Clippy B silverware while Epic rolled up their sleeves and diligently ruined everything So these are the ex guys who still have their self whose stated goal in creating HARD RESET was to recreate that same run fun that characterises older
90s shooters.
Unfortunately, the older 90s shooter that seemed to end up influencing them the most
was QUAKE 2, an experience with about as much variety and entertainment value as drinking
the entire contents of the washing-up bowl the morning after a lard-tasting party.
And HARD RESET's status as a product of former People Can Fly employees makes it comparable
to George Harrison's solo career after The Beatles, no longer the glory days but at least
not as bad as Ring goes.
HARD RESET is a dystopic cyberpunk tale about a bloke named Fletcher, some kind of field
agent or police officer detective thing, in a sprawling corporate future nightmare city
which is to cyberpunk what Tokyo is to the giant monster genre.

The game does the painkiller thing, making multitudes of monsters to mob you mercilessly,
But as with the environments, they forgot the whole variety thing, and you only ever seem to fight two kinds of aggressive Roomba and a few pallet-swapped wheelie bins.
There's really no way of saying this without giving ammunition to conservative anti-game campaigners,
but there isn't as much fun to be had in shooting robots as there is in shooting organic lifeforms.
When I fire a rocket into a cluster of charging monsters, I like to know that the cleanup will have to be done with a mop rather than a broom.

It hard to explain but surely we can all agree that the lawnmower scene from Braindead just wouldn have been as memorable if it had been taking place in the audiovisual department at Harvey Norman Which is to say nothing of the inherent problem of exclusively fighting shiny metallic enemies covered in bleepy lights in a shiny metallic environment covered in bleepy lights
It does get visually confusing and frustrating when you're trying to spot a distant sniper while a charging wheelie bin is trying to use you to redecorate.
Call me crazy, but if your weapon system is based around having two separate guns with four or five unlockable firing modes apiece,
then yes, I suppose you do have a pretty fucking stupid weapon system, but since we're stuck with it,
Surely it would make more sense to have one key that toggles between the two rather than having one key for each.
But now I am nitpicking. Is it fair to criticize an indie game for not having the resources to be as blinged out as previous better-funded games?
Certainly isn't. HARD RESET does end rather abruptly up at the second boss, but at least it's not so long that the repetition gets too dull.
Maybe if I had the time I could play through the plot seven or eight hundred times and finally get what's going on.
And let's fall back on the capitalist's argument that you can't expect too much for under thirty bucks.
Treat HARD RESET as a short, snacky rush of violence one can enjoy to cool down between
big stodgy AAA titles, like having a slightly poorly made cappuccino into twix before going
back to your desk and shoving your head in another bucket of crabs.
